isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - LUBRICATION AND SEALERS - ENGINE OIL SPECIFICATIONS

svcproc.title: OIL QUALITY
svcproc.para: An oil container symbol system has been developed to help you choose the proper oil. The top portion of the symbol shows the oil quality, such as API Service CG-4/SH ( Figure 1). The symbol may show additional categories, such as API Service SG/CE, SF/CE. The center portion will probably show viscosity grade, such as SAE 15W-40 ( Figure 1). If the lower portion shows "Energy Conserving II," be sure the upper and center portions show the correct API service category and proper SAE viscosity grade recommended for your engine.

Oil quality is described by API (American Petroleum Institute) engine service categories. API categories are defined by oil performance (deposits and wear) measured in standard engine tests. API "S" category SH describes oils for spark ignition (gasoline) engines, while "C" categories (CF-4, CG-4) describe oils for diesel engines. Oils with both "S" and "C" categories (such as CG-4/SH) are suitable for both spark ignition and diesel engines. Sometimes, the "S" and "C" categories are reversed (such as SH/CG-4).

The oil quality recommended depends on engine type and engine design. There are many supplementary fuel and oil additives for sale. If you follow the lubricant and oil change interval recommendations, your engine will not require these additives.

note.para: Use of inappropriate API category engine oils severely compromises engine life. It is very important that the recommended or the acceptable alternate API category shown in Table 1, Figure 2be used when selecting engine oil.

caution.para: Do NOT use oils specifically marketed by suppliers for stationary, marine, or railroad diesel engines, or for stationary natural gas engines, even though they are marked API category CD or CE. Such oils can cause excessive valve train wear and combustion chamber deposits. (These oils are sold only in drums or bulk.)
